Question_1.Context: An experiment was conducted to assess the local anesthetic activity of O. anisum root extract using the foot withdrawal reflex in frogs.
Question_1.Question: What was the observed trend in the onset time of anesthesia response with increasing concentrations of O. anisum root extract in the foot withdrawal reflex experiment in frogs?
Question_1.Source: Treatment with different concentrations of methanolic extract of root bark of O. anisum (10–80 mg/mL) revealed the dose-dependent onset time of anesthesia response (35.00, 22.54, 17.35, 12.64 and 6.49 min, respectively) in frog.

Question_2.Context: An experiment was conducted to evaluate the local anesthetic activity of O. anisum root extract using the intradermal wheal method in guinea pigs.
Question_2.Question: What was the observed trend in the onset time of local anesthesia with increasing concentrations of O. anisum root extract in the intradermal wheal method experiment in guinea pigs?
Question_2.Source: Considerable response was observed at guinea pigs treated with 80 mg/mL extract. The quick recovery rate of animals was observed at least concentrations, while the rate of recovery was found to be delayed at higher concentrations.

Question_3.Context: An experiment was conducted to assess the effect of O. anisum root extract on HCl-induced acute lung injury (ALI) in mice.
Question_3.Question: What was the observed effect of O. anisum extract on the total number of inflammatory cells in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) of mice with HCl-induced ALI?
Question_3.Source: Mice administered with different doses of extract before HCl treatment showed considerable reduction in the number of inflammatory cells.

Question_4.Context: An experiment was conducted to evaluate the effect of O. anisum extract on oxidative stress in HCl-induced ALI mice.
Question_4.Question: What was the observed trend in the levels of ROS in the lungs of mice with HCl-induced ALI when treated with O. anisum extract?
Question_4.Source: Mice treated with O. anisum extracts before HCl administration greatly reduced the ROS amounts in the lungs.

Question_5.Context: An experiment was conducted to evaluate the analgesic activity of O. anisum extract using the Eddy’s hot plate method in rats.
Question_5.Question: What was the observed trend in the latency time for analgesia with increasing doses of O. anisum extract in rats?
Question_5.Source: The analysis revealed the increased latency time with significant analgesic activities. The study finds dose-dependent upliftment of latency time with maximal analgesic activity at 200 mg/kg of O. anisum extract.

Question_6.Context: An experiment was conducted to assess the anti-inflammatory activity of O. anisum extract using the carrageenan paw oedema method in rats.
Question_6.Question: What was the observed effect of O. anisum extract on anti-inflammatory activity in rats compared to diclofenac, a known anti-inflammatory agent?
Question_6.Source: Dose-dependent inhibitory activity was observed and the maximal inhibitory activity was monitored at 200 mg/kg of O. ansium extract. However, the anti-inflammatory activity of methanolic extracts of various plants such as Mollugo cerviana, Citrus nobilis, Palicourea crocea, Callicarpa arborea Roxb have been demonstrated previously.

Question_7.Context: An experiment was conducted to evaluate the local anesthetic effect of Anacyclus pyrethrum root extract in guinea pigs.
Question_7.Question: What was the significant finding regarding the local anesthetic effect of Anacyclus pyrethrum root extract in guinea pigs?
Question_7.Source: The animals injected intradermally with plant extract revealed significant local anesthetic effect at 2% ethanolic root extract of A. pyrethrum with rapid onset of time.

Question_8.Context: An experiment was conducted to evaluate the local anesthetic activity of Sterculia tragacantha Lindl extract in guinea pigs.
Question_8.Question: What was the observed effect of Sterculia tragacantha Lindl extract on local anesthesia in guinea pigs?
Question_8.Source: An intradermal injection of extract of Sterculia tragacantha Lindl displayed local anesthetic activity in guinea pig.

Question_9.Context: An experiment was conducted to assess the anti-inflammatory potential of O. anisum root extract using a mice model of HCl-induced ALI.
Question_9.Question: What was the observed effect of O. anisum root extract on the number of inflammatory cells in BALF of mice with HCl-induced ALI?
Question_9.Source: Mice administered orally with different doses of O. anisum root extract showed reduced number of inflammatory cells in BALF.

Question_10.Context: An experiment was conducted to evaluate the effect of O. anisum extract on redox homeostasis and catalase activity in HCl-induced ALI mice.
Question_10.Question: What was the observed effect of O. anisum extract on redox homeostasis and catalase activity in lungs of mice with HCl-induced ALI?
Question_10.A: No effect on redox homeostasis and catalase activity
Question_10.B: Decrease in redox homeostasis and catalase activity
Question_10.C: Increase in redox homeostasis and catalase activity
Question_10.D: Fluctuation in redox homeostasis and catalase activity
Question_10.Source: Results unveiled that mice treated with O. anisum extract was found to restore the redox homeostasis and catalase activity in lungs.
